job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clarksville, TN
pros: The campus environment is pleasant, friendly and supportive. The interaction with students is inspiring. The camaraderie is real. The schedule is really flexible.
cons: The jobs tend to be temporary, with very little room for advancement as a staff member. Faculty personnel have to decide whether they will maintain side work and, as with all colleges, tenure is a tough path. It is not the right place for the ambitious or those seeking significant financial rewards.

pros: I loved the people I worked with and management was always helpful and kind. They are also lenient when you need time off.
cons: I didn't agree with the way some things were done, and many of the tutors felt like we couldn't do anything about it. Students tended to use tutors to get a slip that said they attended a session and then blamed you when their grades were bad. Management supported its tutors for the most part. Online submitters will send in the same paper 100 times until you fix every single error, and you don't have the power to tell them you won't review their paper again (and eventually you see a paper so many times that you've written it at this point and it's probably plagiarism).

pros:

review_title: Not terrible, but I wouldn't mind some changes.
pros: We have a lot of really great programs in place to keep faculty active in research and learning. Our students are down-to-earth. I love them! I love the opportunities and benefits I've been given there. I've been offered other jobs, but have not taken them because they didn't offer me what I had at the Peay.
cons: We rely too heavily on adjunct labor. Because of our location, we don't always get great interview pools and have hired people we have regretted and it's very hard to get rid of them due to the tenure process. It makes me absolutely abhor my department. Our pay during the school year is a joke compared to comparable schools.

review_title: Undergrad work is what it is
pros: The working environment is generally pleasant for students. The amount you learn is highly dependent on what department you end up working in. If you already possess high-level skill with computer software such as Excel (and I mean you are able to do pivotTables, etc.), you may be entrusted with higher-level projects.
cons: Some professors are just jerks, and they will let you know. Watch out for idiotic bickering between professors. It happens in some departments and you can find yourself embroiled in it if you give anyone your sympathy. Just stay out of it. APSU doesn't pay anyone much, so expect to make very little while you are there.

review_title: Some great deparments to work for!
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Clarksville, TN
pros: The benefits are what keep most people working at APSU.  There is state retirement, week long paid holiday at Christmas, good insurance rates, free education for staff and 50% discount for spouse and children.
cons: Salary is below standard compared to other universities.  Some of the departments on campus have leaders that are less than desirable to work for, but most are good.  Parking is almost impossible due to very limited staff parking spaces.  You must arrive pretty early in order to get a good parking spot.

pros: I worked as a student, so i really enjoyed the freedom of having a job that did not compete with my class schedule.
cons: I really didn't like the inconsistency in expectations, nor did i not like the buddy system for doing things. It's just me. I don't don't like office politics.

pros: I love working with people and solving problems. Austin Peay was a great place to work while I was in school. I really appreciate the benefits and the pay I received.
cons: Shame it took up too much study time. I could see myself possibly working here full time some day. I hope that opportunity avails itself.

review_title: Poor work-life balance, but okay everywhere else.
pros: I feel that my opinions have value. I am asked to contribute and my contributions have an impact on my department.
cons: We are experiencing a surge in student growth. That's great, but we don't have the professors to keep up with the demand. The average professor-student ratio is 18, yet I have over 100 advisees.
